title: Who's responsibility is it to clean and transform data?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Match the method to the data type
1. Data cleaning
body:
Data cleaning is the process of identify and correcting issues with the data.

It should never be assumed that data is suitable for the intended use. Every dataset should be checked for accuracy, completeness, duplicates and currency.

title: Summary
body:
Before data can be used as part of a project, the quality and fitness for purpose of that data needs to be checked.

It should never be assumed that data is suitable for the intended use. Every dataset should be checked for accuracy, completeness, duplicates and currency. In addition the data will most likely need to be transformed or combined with other data to make the data conform to specific quality standards. 

The process of cleaning and transforming data can take substantial time. Depending on the scale, rate and method of acquisition of data it might be advisable to automate the cleaning and transforming process. 

Additionally, if might be necessary to go back a stage in your data lifecycle and change the requirements or collection technique to help reduce the errors and inconsistencies in the the data at time of collection.

Regardless, a manual validation and fitness for purpose tests will still need to be carried out before conclusions can be drawn from the data. The next module looks at how we can use Exploratory Data Analysis to perform these validation checks.

title: Where are we?
body: We have reached a critical stage in the data lifecycle, data cleaning. Data cleaning is the process of identifying errors and inconsistencies in the dataset and either removing or flagging these for later. Even if a rigorous approach is taken to specify data requirements, gather and store data, there are still highly likely to be errors and inconsistencies in the data. Further, data may be sourced from other projects and the method of collection may have not suited the requirements of your particular project; the data may need to be transformed to make it suitable for the goals and objectives of your project.

title: Why transform data?
body: In addition to the points mentioned previously, why else might it be necessary to transform data?

_items.text: To ensure we get the required result
To prevent others from accessing data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Before proceeding to the next stage of data analysis you should double check that the data does not contain any records or attributes that we are not legally allowed to use or retain. Additionally, there maybe ethical issues to consider, both related to the data and also goals of the project. These may also be raised in next stage on Exploratory Data Analysis.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Before proceeding to the next stage of data analysis you should double check that the data does not contain any records or attributes that we are not legally allowed to use or retain. Additionally, there maybe ethical issues to consider, both related to the data and also goals of the project. These may also be raised in next stage on Exploratory Data Analysis.

title: 2. Transforming data
body: Transforming data is the process of converting data from one structure or format to another. It may also involve the process of combining data with existing or newly sourced data.

title: Match the method to the data type
Match the method to the data type?
Considerations when transforming data
body:
There are many ways to transform data. As with data cleaning, this can be done manually, semi-manual or automatically. The methods and tools used depend on a few considerations including:

  • How many times will the data need transforming
  • The complexity of the changes required
  • The size of the data
  • The frequency (or velocity) of updates/additions to the data
  • The skills and tools you have available

title: Keeping track
body: At the end of the data cleaning and transforming process, the data is likely to look significantly different from that originally acquired. In order to help keep track of processes affecting the data, which of the following must we keep on record:

_items.text: A copy of the originally acquired data
An audit log of the changes to the data at each stage
A copy of the data after each individual cleaning and transforming operation
The list of names of who is to blame for the bad quality data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

It is important to maintain accurate data lineage records; a record data's origins, what happens to it and where it moves over time.

It is also paramount to maintain a copy of the originally acquired data (during the data lifecycle) such that it is possible to backtrack all the way to the beginning if mistakes are made. 

Many pieces of cleaning software automatically keep operational logs that can be exported as part of the audit trail.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

It is important to maintain accurate data lineage records; a record data's origins, what happens to it and where it moves over time.

It is also paramount to maintain a copy of the originally acquired data (during the data lifecycle) such that it is possible to backtrack all the way to the beginning if mistakes are made. 

Many pieces of cleaning software automatically keep operational logs that can be exported as part of the audit trail.

title: Match the method to the data type
displayTitle: Match the method to the data type
body: See if you can match the method for cleaning and transforming with the described data.
placeholder: Please select the minimal acceptable method. All can be done automatically.

_items.text: A static, one off, small dataset of 10 rows and 3 columns.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

With small, static data, manual cleaning and transformation is just as quick, efficient and accurate as designing a semi-manual and automated process. 

Tools like Excel are OK to use, however blanket use of find and replace should be avoided without carefully specifying the range of the search. As a simple example, replacing "f" with "female" and "m" with "male" (in that order) will result in "male" and "femaleale" as there is an "m" in female.   

It is advisable to use tools like Open Refine for small scale changes.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

With small, static data, manual cleaning and transformation is just as quick, efficient and accurate as designing a semi-manual and automated process. 

Tools like Excel are OK to use, however blanket use of find and replace should be avoided without carefully specifying the range of the search. As a simple example, replacing "f" with "female" and "m" with "male" (in that order) will result in "male" and "femaleale" as there is an "m" in female.   

It is advisable to use tools like Open Refine for small scale changes.

title: Errors
body: Can you spot all the different types of errors in the data shown here.
instruction: Enter your answers as grid cell coordinates, for example E3 refers to the value "826".

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

It is hard to believe such a small amount of data could contain so many errors. If we assume flight number is unique in a 24 hour period, did you also spot the redundant row of data?

  • Spelling error (F3)
  • Redundant data (Row 5)
  • Missing value (F5)
  • Date errors (B3 & B4)
  • Invalid value (B4)
  • Data type error (E2)
  • Multiple representation (C6)

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

 

It is hard to believe such a small amount of data could contain so many errors. If we assume flight number is unique in a 24 hour period, did you also spot the redundant row of data?

  • Spelling error (F3)
  • Redundant data (Row 5)
  • Missing value (F5)
  • Date errors (B3 & B4)
  • Invalid value (B4)
  • Data type error (E2)
  • Multiple representation (C6)

title: Methods for cleaning data
body: Once datasets increase in size, a visual quality check of the raw data may become impractical. There are however a number of summary techniques that can be used to help clean data.

_items.title: Frequency tables and facets
_items.body:
One of the best ways to validate data is to use frequency tables (or facets).

A frequency table will summarise the range of values an attribute has. For example, the image here shows a frequency table being used to highlight inconsistencies in the names of airline companies.

Frequency tables can also be used to identify incorrect data types and check the range of values present against those allowed.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Statistical and outlier analysis
_items.body:
If you are dealing with numerical data, some simple exploratory data analysis can help validate the input data. 

Calculation of the averages (mean, median and mode) can help identify the distribution of the data and the presence of outliers. 

This can also be done visually with a histogram, box-and-whisker or scatter plot (as shown).

Identification of outliers is also critical to help identify use of mixed numerical scales. 

For more on the use of these methods, please refer to the exploratory data analysis module.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Codified fixing
_items.body:
Data cleaning can become a very repetitive task, especially when needing to be done at scale or on a regular basis.

Using data processing workflow software or developing code to automate the checks is an efficient way to scale up the cleaning process. 

Commonly such software will validate the data against the defined schema, such as csvlint.io. 

It is also possible to automate the data cleaning process. OpenRefine allows you to export the cleaning operations as structured code that can be run in a new Refine project or even translated into queries to be executed on a database or via a macro in excel.

title: Why transform data?
body:
Transforming the data is important in a number of common scenarios:

  • To work with data in a particular software (e.g. in a specific format)
  • To combine data from multiple sources 
  • To normalise data types into the same units, categories and scales. 
  • To make the data conform to a specific data standard
  • To enable a specific type of analysis
  • To create a set of derived data or attributes (e.g. a calculated value)

title: Common errors in data
body: There are a number of common errors in data that you should look out for in any dataset you are working with.

_items.title: Missing values
_items.body:
Beware blank or "null" values in any dataset unless you are certain you know what they mean.

Worse than a missing value is when an arbitrary value is used instead. For example "  ",0,NULL or even " " might actually be trying to represent a blank value.  

Watch out for dates in 1900, 1904, 1969 and 1970. For reasons beyond obscure, Excel's default date from which it counts all other dates is January 1st, 1900, unless you're using Excel on a Mac, in which case it's January 1st, 1904. Many databases and applications will often generate a date of 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z or 1969-12-31T23:59:59Z which is the Unix epoch for timestamps. In other words this is what happens when a system tries to display an empty value or a 0 value as a date.

Any time you're working with data that has missing values you should ask yourself: "Do I know what the absence of this value means?" If the answer is no, you should ask your source.

_items.title: Incomplete data
_items.body:
If you know what the data is meant to be about, then you can check for incomplete data. 

For example, if you have a dataset covering the United States then you can check to ensure all 50 states are represented. 

If the dataset should confirm to a schema or standard you can also check that all attributes are present.

_items.title: Data type errors
_items.body:
Many errors in data occur due to lack of validation on data entry, thus data does not conform to the specified schema. 

A common error is the presence of text in a numerical field (e.g. "5-star" instead of 5). 

Alternatively you might just have an invalid value, e.g. a country in a county field or a decimal where you should have a whole number. 

Conversely, the validation might be too harsh and exclude data. Be exceptionally aware of this problem when working with topics where definitions tend to be arbitrary, such as race or ethnicity. 

What does "other" really mean?

_items.title: Inconsistent date formats
_items.body:
Dates can be written in inconsistent ways. Mixed date formats are sometimes simple to spot:

8-sep-2013 vs 8/9/2013

and sometimes less obvious:

8/9/2013 vs 9/8/2013.

Another challenge is that some applications, like Excel, will ‘guess’ the format when a dataset is opened, which can hide how dates are actually written in the file.

The most common error is the mixed use of American (MM/DD/YYYY) and European (DD/MM/YYYY) formats.

_items.title: Multiple representations
_items.body:
People often try to save time when entering data by abbreviating terms. If these abbreviations are not consistent, it can cause errors in the dataset.

Differences in capitalisation, spacing and genders of adjectives can all cause errors.

_items.title: Duplicate records
_items.body:
A duplicate record is where the same piece of data has been entered more than once. Duplicate records often occur when datasets have been combined or because it was not known there was already an entry.

Note: Duplicate records can be useful to verify data. For instance if two different sources of data contain similar data the two can be cross validated against each other.

_items.title: Redundant  data
_items.body:
Redundant data is anything that is not relevant to your work with the dataset. Often a dataset has been created for a specific purpose which requires details you may not need.

Common occurrences of redundant data include rows that represent total amounts.

Other times columns of data have been combined or replicated in order to assist human readability.

_items.title: Missing unique identifiers
_items.body:
Ideally every record should have a globally unique identifier. 

This helps identify duplicate data, especially when data is combined with other data. 

Unfortunately many database applications use an incrementing number as an identifier. While this works in a single table, it is not a globally unique identifier.

_items.title: Mixed numerical scales
_items.body:
Numerical values in datasets often use different scales to make it easier for a human to read. These are often caused because the units of collection are not specified.

In budget datasets, for example, the units are often in the millions. 1,200,000 often becomes 1.2m. However, smaller amounts like 8,000 may still be written in full. For a machine, this means they read the larger figure as 1.2, or the smaller value as 8,000,000,000.

_items.title: Spelling errors
_items.body:
Spelling errors are often difficult to identify in tabular data.

Don’t forget to run your data through a spell-checker to catch spelling errors.

_items.title: Invalid values
_items.body:
In addition to data type errors, you might also find your dataset has invalid values of the correct data type. 

For example, if a date field is not limited can people enter dates of birth in the future? 

Careful control over ranges and vocabularies helps ensure these errors are kept to a minimum.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Dealing with missing data
body:
If it is not possible to fix the data, there are two main approaches for handling missing data, exclusion and interpolation. 

It is very important to be aware of the potential impact of these on the data:

Is the data still a representative sample of the population?

Has the exclusion or interpolation process introduced bias?

_items.title: Excluding data
_items.body:
Exclusion is the removal of an entire record in the sample. 

Excluding a record may be done for many reasons, one of which may be because of the low quality, extreme nature or duplication of the record. 

In addition there may well be inclusion or exclusion criteria that control which records are acceptable in a sample (e.g. age of participant).

_items.title: Interpolating data
_items.body:
Interpolation is the creation of new data values derived from estimates generated from the existing data values.

For example, if a traffic counter breaks for one hour during a day, the values will not be zero. Interpolation using values from the hours before and after can help fill the gap and ensure them sample remains representative. 

Interpolation may also be used to create a synthetic dataset that is representative but does not contain any real data (e.g. an anonymous dataset).

title: How to fix errors in data?
displayTitle: How to fix errors in data?
body: Once you have identified the errors and inconsistencies in your data, what approach should you take to fix them?

_items.text: Check against the schema to find out the valid values
Change the values to match the majority
Remove the records containing bad quality data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The temptation is to make the dataset consistent through a majority vote; if three dates are in one format and two in another, then do we assume that the minority are wrong?

The correct approach is to check against the schema for that dataset to discover what, if any, constraints there are on values in the dataset. 

Removing records should be avoided where possible but may be necessary in some cases, such as the record being a clear outlier.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The temptation is to make the dataset consistent through a majority vote; if three dates are in one format and two in another, then do we assume that the minority are wrong?

The correct approach is to check against the schema for that dataset to discover what, if any, constraints there are on values in the dataset. 

Removing records should be avoided where possible but may be necessary in some cases, such as the record being a clear outlier.

title: Cleaning & Transforming Data
body:
Before data can be used as part of a project, the quality and fitness for purpose of that data needs to be checked. There are three main stages in this process:

  1. Data cleaning - Identifying and correcting issues with data
  2. Data transformation - Converting the data to different formats or structures
  3. Exploratory data analysis - Examining the dataset to identify bias and test hypothesis.

This module examines the process of cleaning and transforming data ready for analysis. Data cleaning is the essential first step. Exploratory data analysis may happen before or after data transformation.

title: Who's responsibility is it to clean and transform data?
displayTitle: Who's responsibility is it to clean and transform data?
body:
It is the responsibility of the user of the data to ensure it is fit for purpose. 

During the inception phase of a project, expectations should be set around who is responsible for cleaning and transforming the data. If possible, work with the organisation or client who provides the data as only they are likely to understand the full meaning of the data (e.g. what missing values mean). 

Even if the data provider takes responsibility for cleaning and transforming the data, validation checks should still be put in place to ensure that this is happening.

_items.text: A database containing 200 rows of data. Updated once a year.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

For a small scale database, a set of macros or database queries can be used.

This process is more suited towards larger, but still static datasets. 

Tools like Open Refine can not only help you clean the data, but the change process can be exported as code via the undo/redo tab and then applied to future datasets simply by pasting the change process.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

For a small scale database, a set of macros or database queries can be used.

This process is more suited towards larger, but still static datasets. 

Tools like Open Refine can not only help you clean the data, but the change process can be exported as code via the undo/redo tab and then applied to future datasets simply by pasting the change process.

title: Match the method to the data type
displayTitle: Match the method to the data type
body: See if you can match the method for cleaning and transforming with the described data.
placeholder: Please select the minimal acceptable method. All can be done automatically.

_items.text: A live data feed from a transport company.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

As data gets larger, or more dynamic, then automation is required to clean and transform the data. 

Many companies build their entire business from cleaning, transforming and combining data from multiple sources to be consumed by customers in a clean, consistent, standards compliant format. 

In addition to custom adapters, tools like FME or AWS Glue provide off the shelf solutions for automated transformation of data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

As data gets larger, or more dynamic, then automation is required to clean and transform the data. 

Many companies build their entire business from cleaning, transforming and combining data from multiple sources to be consumed by customers in a clean, consistent, standards compliant format. 

In addition to custom adapters, tools like FME or AWS Glue provide off the shelf solutions for automated transformation of data.

title: Methods for cleaning data
body:
Manual cleaning: Using tools like Excel. The process is entirely manual and might make a lot of use of "find and replace". 

Tools like Excel are OK to use, however blanket use of find and replace should be avoided without carefully specifying the range of the search. As a simple example, replacing "f" with "female" and "m" with "male" (in that order) will result in "male" and "femaleale" as there is an "m" in female.   

Semi-manual cleaning: The process is still driven by a human, but use of macros and code snippets are used to ensure consistency of the performed operation. This is safer than a manual change, however a human still has to remember to run the cleaning operations, potentially in the right order. 

Automatic cleaning:  Here both the cleaning operation and point of execution of the cleaning are automatic; no human input is required. Automated cleaning may well act directly on the data in the database or at point of acquisition.
